rows.field_645009:
As a fairly dark shade, this color is ideal for coloring smaller elements (like text and buttons). Due to its darkness, it provides excellent contrast, even when used against a white background. The readability of the text is perfectly acceptable.
C:80%, M:60%, Y:0%, K:20%

It's a dark blue shade; this color could easily be used to color smaller elements (like text and buttons). Due to its darkness, it provides excellent contrast when used against a white background. Text readability is perfectly acceptable.
C:80%, M:67%, Y:0%, K:0%

This is an excellent pale yellow shade. As a fairly light shade, this color works well as a fill/background for larger elements as well. If there is no obvious reason to use it as a text color on white backgrounds, we do not recommend it (low contrast gives bad accessibility-rating).
C:0%, M:20%, Y:80%, K:0%

It's an excellent shade of light orange. As a fairly light shade, this color works well as a fill/background color, as well as a background color for larger elements. We do not recommend using it as a text color on white backgrounds unless there is an obvious reason for doing so (low contrast gives bad accessability-rating).
C:0%, M:40%, Y:100%, K:0%
This is the main font for our brand's assets, in it's regular variant. It's recommended to use this font in all our published materials.
This is the main font for our brand's assets, in it's bold variant. It's recommended to use this font in all our published materials.
This is the main font for our brand's assets, in it's italics variant. It's recommended to use this font in all our published materials.
An emoji made just for our brand. Use this emoji in all our communications to leave brand recall.

rows.field_644944: The header needs to be improved to make the CTA clearer.
The structure is a little off, so we may need to adjust the sitemap here as well.
The new footer should include our contact information and also a small (but clear) CTA.
The authentication process is currently experiencing some bugs. We need to ensure these bugs are worked out.
The left panel on the dashboard needs updating in terms of content.
We should aim to include new reports beyond what we currently offer.
There are some new design trends that we can incorporate into this dashboard.
The migration should be fairly painless if we use the right tools.
We don't need to set everything up to be automated yet, but this is something we should keep in the back of our minds.
Could we get creative and skip traditional presentation software to achieve this?
No need to publish it right away, but let's have it internally at least.

rows.field_648108: The Conservation Fund (Material Culture Studies Of The Seventeenth And Eighteenth-Century Chesapeake)
rows.field_648113: Adriana Green (Curator of Indigenous Arts of the Americas, The Fralin Museum of Art at the University of Virginia)
rows.field_648115: https://networks.h-net.org/node/73374/announcements/4044022/call-grant-applications-material-culture-studies-seventeenth; The grant is For Material Culture Studies Of The Seventeenth And Eighteenth-Century Chesapeake and our project is to study pottery shards impressed with Native-made textiles, from selected collections in the Chesapeake including Flowerdew and Historic Jamestowne, to recover information about the textiles that produced the imprinting.  More broadly, we will be researching comparable Indigenous textile fragments in collections and in the ethnographic record, and also consult with contemporary textile weavers who work with similar or same materials.  3D scanning/printing of select pieces will help visualize textile details and facilitate conversations with Native community partners.    We hope to be able to scan a range of pieces; selections from the Flowerdew collection being of course the most manageable logistically for you, but Historic Jamestowne appears open to 3D scanning some of their pieces, and we can see about others once they are identified.  The overall span of the grant period is in the range of 2 years, with a publication at the end.  I am on this as the UVa Curator that I am, since ethnographic/contemporary basketry are part of my areas of research; Beth Bollwerk who is archaeologist already working with Flowerdew (we have discussed this with Meg Kennedy, who is now overseeing that collection);  Buck Woodward, anthropologist, who is spearheading this project and works with VA Native tribes in a variety of projects/consultations; and Nottoway Indian Tribe as tribal partners.  Named collaborator (Rourk)
Help professor and his students create immersive visualizations/VR of fish wake structures. Named collaborators (Rourk, Bennett)

rows.field_648120: "The Digits team is hard at work interviewing folks in preparation for writing our second white paper on the socio-technical needs of DH stakeholders and we'd very much like to interview some of the folks at Scholars' Lab (or UVA more generally) to talk to them about their digital workflows... We're specifically interested in (1) digital makers who have faced barriers in hosting, sustainability, or system maintenance; (2) journal editors and publishers who seek to accept unconventional digital content; and (3) libraries and archives intending to preserve digital materials."

rows.field_648116: Erin White and her team of three: designer, developer, and UX researcher
Whitney Sperrazza (Hall Center for the Humanities)
rows.field_648120:
"First, I'm thinking about my own research, which is very interested in the intersections of digital and physical. I'd love to chat with SLab staff members who help faculty and students develop makerspace projects, from nascent idea through design and building. It'll be especially helpful to hear what works well for such collaborations, and I'm always looking for new models of research that works at these same intersections. Unfortunately, we don't have nearly the same level of project support and development yet at KU, so I'm eager to learn from your wealth of knowledge while I'm there."
"Second, I'm visiting in order to learn more about how the SLab and makerspaces function. The Hall Center for the Humanities and Institute for Digital Research (currently separate entities) at KU are doing some brainstorming for how to restructure KU's digital profile, and they've asked me to learn more about some of the most successful models. So, I hope you don't mind also sharing a bit about the structure of SLab, its mission, its staffing, etc. - any information will be super useful"

rows.field_648116: Avery Weems (Director of Scholars Lab and Data Librarian)
rows.field_648120: "We're launching a digital scholarship lab at Abilene Christian University in Abilene, TX and hoped you might be willing to video- or phone-conference with us for 30-45 minutes sometime in the near future to discuss your experience and model at UVA.   We have five or so questions we could send to you as a starting point. "

rows.field_648117: University of Hawaii's at Manoa's Hamilton Library
rows.field_648120:
"I'm writing to you from the University of Hawaii's at Manoa's Hamilton Library, where we are currently looking into creating a Digital Scholarship Lab. I've been tasked with learning how Digital Humanities/Digital Scholarship centers operate on other campuses, and I'm reaching out to you in hopes that you might help with benchmarking.
While much of the current specifications of digital labs are listed on their respective websites, as someone interested in developing a lab many of the things I'm interested in are less clear. While I've read a some about the creation and organization of the Scholars' Lab ("Skunks in the Library" was one of the first texts I read in library school) I'm sure that there are many day-to-day operational considerations which are hard to appreciate from the outside. Since the Scholars' Lab is one of the oldest and most respected library DH centers, I'm also very interested in what you would consider essential features for new Digital Scholarship centers. I'd be grateful for any help and guidance you're able to give."

rows.field_648116: Rikk Mulligan (CMU?) and Erla Heyns & Matthew Hannah (Purdue)
Heather Lee, Global Network Asst. Prof. at NYU & Asst. Prof. in History, NUY Shanghai

rows.field_648120: After Laura Miller and Amanda Visconti gave an invited talk and advised their deans and department chairs on how to start a digital humanities initiative, they liked our talk enough that they raised funds to come visit SLab. Seven people, including a dean, the English Department Chair, two faculty in philosophy and religious studies, and one in English, plus librarians, spent over two days meeting with Scholars' Lab staff and IATH.

"Looking on your website, I especially love seeing the different digital projects in the humanities, like the Neatline exhibition. I was wondering if you would ever consider doing a virtual workshop, via video conferencing, to highlight some of the ways you use ArcGIS or Neatline for research? We are looking to program some events in the Fall of this year, either in September or early November. I know our faculty would be really interested to see and hear what you are doing."
rows.field_648121: 2nd contact from this Abilene Christian University Library new "Scholars Lab"

rows.field_648116: Catherine Winters, Library Digital Humanities User Interface Developer
rows.field_648120: VR guidance from Arin
Reimagined dissertations from Amanda
DH dissertations from Amanda

"Very impressed with your website and other projects so thought I would inquire" about text analysis: "I was tasked with performing an historical analysis of the annual Presidential keynote addresses from 1902-2018 given at the meeting of the largest group in the US for urologists, the American Urological Association (AUA).  I have all 112 files as ordered text documents and was hoping to look at word trends over time within broad categories such as optimism vs. pessimism, conservative vs liberal, etc.  I don't have access to Python or R and so apart from analog techniques (e.g. reading) I would have no ability to do any high-throughput digital analysis other than what I can do with word statistics like 'readability'."

rows.field_648116: Steven Reader (Associate Professor of Geography, School of Geosciences at the University of South Florida)
rows.field_648120: "this summer I am working for our Dean of the Tampa (main) Campus Library. My original mandate was to come up with a plan for how the USF System Libraries offer GIS related services into the future, but as I have researched the digital transformations taking place in academic libraries, I think we have agreed to expand my mandate somewhat, particularly as GIS interfaces with so many different disciplines. In looking at how other academic libraries have been addressing the challenges and opportunities of digital technologies, the Scholars Lab at UVA has stood out to me... I am trending towards a ‘skunkworks’ mode of thinking in terms of library collaborations/engagement that might involve these two areas, plus other digital technologies and data sciences. As you might appreciate, this is why I am attracted to the Scholars Lab... What I would most like to do is visit the Scholars Lab at UVA to meet with you and your staff. I would really enjoy witnessing the Scholars Lab firsthand and would appreciate the insights and perspectives that you and your staff could provide, both on the Scholars Lab itself, and the broader arena of digital technologies and libraries."

rows.field_648116: Gregory Isoldi, Office of Campus Planning and Facilities Management
rows.field_648120: "The Office of Campus Planning  and Facilities Management are looking to introduce a Makerspace or Innovation Lab of our own.  I am trying to collect as much research as possible in order to create the best available space.  I was wondering if you would be able to elaborate more on your facilities.  For example, Who Pays for the maintenance of the facility? As well as what safeguards are used to protect the students, and are their required Trainings to operate the machinery?"

rows.field_645147: metaLAB Portfolio: Projects and Provocations, 2011–2019
rows.field_645152: "metaLAB began in 2011 as team of makers and thinkers betwixt and between the disciplines, sharing a vision for the digital arts and humanities that was playful, inventive, and visionary. Nine years, 36 grants, and hundreds of projects later, we’re still growing strong. The metaLAB portfolio is an index to those years of adventure, a document of projects and discoveries, and a harbinger of things to come."

rows.field_645147: Meditation on Abolition
rows.field_645152: Pamphlet/chapbook by UVA faculty member Ashon Crawley.
rows.field_678890: "In Meditation on Abolition, Ashon Crawley discusses how the spiritual community of his youth, Blackpentecostalism, gave him a way into abolition as a practice of concern, as a practice of care. He demonstrates that any community formation or institutional practice has within the capacity to be disrupted by the liberative energies of abolitionist practice. It can be disrupted when we commit daily to enacting abolition—not just with regard to incarceration but in all our relationships, friendships, comraderly engagements. When practiced daily, in the mundane, abolition can become the reflexive posture from which to sense the world and act with, in and through it." (Publisher blurb)

rows.field_645163: Coding Rights and the Design Justice Network
rows.field_680601: "This oracle is a hands-on card deck designed to help us collectively envision and share ideas for transfeminist technologies from the future. Throughout history, human beings have used a wide variety of divination procedures – such as tarot decks – as technologies to understand the present and reshape our destinies. The wisdom of the oracle, embedded with transfeminist values, will help us foresee a future where technologies are designed by people who are too often excluded from or targeted by technology in today's world." (Authors)

rows.field_668000: We can make as many copies as people wish to take
Digital version that can't be printed to make another copy of zine. Add additional tag if there is a separate print zine(s) we own as well.

We have limitations on lending or distributing copies, but an interested reader may opt to purchase their own copy for as long as the creator offers this. Some of these may offer a sliding scale or request a donation from $0+.

We only have one copy paid from personal rather than UVA funds, and can't acquire or create more. These zines have limitations on use to avoid loss, e.g. only reading within the lab, or only borrowing by people with enough history with the lab we can expect its return by an agreed date. Limitations to acquiring more copies could include cost, special assembly or material requirements, or access (e.g. no longer in print and not locally reprintable from file/xerox; author request or licensing)

We only have 2-3 copies and these were paid from personal rather than UVA funds, and can't acquire or create more.
